docs.lead_paragraph: Polls will tell you that a majority of Americans recognize the need to raise taxes. A group of about two-dozen American millionaires have signed a letter to Congress asking for tax hikes that would affect them directly. They even sent a delegation to Washington today to make that case.

headline.main: Grover and the Giant No-Taxes Pledge

docs.abstract: If the supercommittee declares a stalemate, blame Grover Norquist.
docs.snippet: If the supercommittee declares a stalemate, blame Grover Norquist.

docs.abstract: Putting off political decisions seems to come easily to President Obama. Is that why we're still trying to figure out who he is?
docs.snippet: Putting off political decisions seems to come easily to President Obama. Is that why we're still trying to figure out who he is?

docs.lead_paragraph: For some time the Obama administration had appeared to be signaling its likely approval of a plan to lay a high-pressure oil pipeline from Canadian tar sands right on top of the main water supply to much of the Midwest. Last week, however, after thousands of protesters - ranging from ranchers and farmers to ordinary Americans concerned about the catastrophic harm that could be done if that pipeline were to leak - surrounded the White House, the administration announced that it was delaying a decision until 2013.
docs.abstract: Putting off political decisions seems to come easily to President Obama. Is that why we're still trying to figure out who he is?
docs.snippet: Putting off political decisions seems to come easily to President Obama. Is that why we're still trying to figure out who he is?

headline.main: Employers Step Up Efforts to Curb Health Care Costs

docs.abstract: Mercer finds that employers are facing increases of about 6 percent in average employee benefit costs.
docs.snippet: Mercer finds that employers are facing increases of about 6 percent in average employee benefit costs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Employers remain concerned about the relentless increase in the cost of providing health coverage for their workers, according to a new survey, and many companies are trying to do more about it.

headline.main: Employers Step Up Efforts to Curb Health Care Costs

docs.lead_paragraph: The Wisest Entrepreneurs Know How to Preserve Equity  |  So you want to be an Internet billionaire. It's not just about having a great idea and building a world-class business at light speed, writes Steven M. Davidoff in his Deal Professor column.
The Constitution supports the mandate to buy health insurance.

headline.seo: Health Insurance and the Broccoli Test

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Harvard law professor Einer Elhauge asserts that the mandate to purchase health insurance, which will be judged by the Supreme Court, is supported by the Constitution; offers legal argument that proves that the mandate clearly falls under the Congress's right to regulate commerce.
docs.snippet: The Constitution supports the mandate to buy health insurance.

docs.lead_paragraph: After decades of decay, Owensboro is generating new entertainment, hotel, housing, retail, and office development with the support of an $80 million tax increase.

headline.seo: In Owensboro, Ky., a Tax Increase Helps Revitalize Downtown
headline.main: A Kentucky City Reinvents a Faded Downtown
headline.print_headline: A Kentucky City Reinvents a Faded Downtown

docs.abstract: Owensboro, Kentucky, following decades of decay, is generating new entertainment, hotel, housing, retail, and office development with the support of an $80 million tax increase; Mayor Ron Pane has overseen more than $1 billion in development, with much of it concentrated in the recovering downtown area.
docs.snippet: After decades of decay, Owensboro is generating new entertainment, hotel, housing, retail, and office development with the support of an $80 million tax increase.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama is in the awkward position of defending something he once rejected as a candidate.

headline.seo: Insurance Mandate May Be Health Law’s Undoing
headline.main: Insurance Mandate May Be Health Bill’s Undoing
headline.print_headline: Obama’s Shift on Mandate May Be Health Law’s Undoing

docs.abstract: News analysis; Pres Obama may regret his shift away from the rejection of mandatory health insurance, articulated early in his 2008 campaign; the Supreme Court has agreed to take up a constitutional challenge to his health care reform law, and a decision to reject the provision requiring nearly all Americans to buy coverage could come in the midst of his 2012 re-election campaign.
docs.snippet: President Obama is in the awkward position of defending something he once rejected as a candidate.
